title: Playbook
text:
Quarto Graft keeps contributors in small, safe branches while the trunk curates a single site.
This page explains the hats a quarto-graft wears during the development of the website.





Work only in their graft branch.
Never merge back ‚Äì their content is pulled in by the trunk.
Typical loop:

git checkout my-graft-branch
‚Ä¶working on the content‚Ä¶
make preview
git commit and git push






Owns the main trunk.
Controls the inventory grafts.yaml and grafts.lock.
Maintains docs/_quart.yaml and site branding.
Run trunk builds, publishing pipelines.
Owns graft lifecycle: graft-new, graft-list, graft-destroy, graft-cleanup-orphans





Propose and evolve the starter skeletons used for new grafts.
Submit changes via PRs to main; maintainers promote accepted templates into the templates/ folder.

title: Jupyter Notebook Example
text:
Quick check that the graft package imports and runs.


Show the code
from jupyter_demo import greet, show_dataframe

greet("branch builder")




Show the code
show_dataframe()

title: Intro
text: import%20marimo%20as%20mo%0A%0Amo.md(%22%23%20Welcome%20to%20marimo!%20%F0%9F%8C%8A%F0%9F%8D%83%22)

title: Intro
text:
1. Reactive execution
A marimo notebook is made up of small blocks of Python code called cells.
marimo reads your cells and models the dependencies among them: whenever a cell that defines a global variable is run, marimo automatically runs all cells that reference that variable.
Reactivity keeps your program state and outputs in sync with your code, making for a dynamic programming environment that prevents bugs before they happen.

    
    
    
    (%0A%20%20%20%20mo.md(%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20f%22%22%22%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20**%E2%9C%A8%20Nice!**%20The%20value%20of%20%60changed%60%20is%20now%20%7Bchanged%7D.%0A%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20When%20you%20updated%20the%20value%20of%20the%20variable%20%60changed%60%2C%20marimo%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20**reacted**%20by%20running%20this%20cell%20automatically%2C%20because%20this%20cell%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20references%20the%20global%20variable%20%60changed%60.%0A%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20Reactivity%20ensures%20that%20your%20notebook%20state%20is%20always%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20consistent%2C%20which%20is%20crucial%20for%20doing%20good%20science%3B%20it's%20also%20what%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20enables%20marimo%20notebooks%20to%20double%20as%20tools%20and%20%20apps.%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%22%22%22%0A%20%20%20%20)%0A%20%20%20%20if%20changed%0A%20%20%20%20else%20mo.md(%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%22%22%22%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20**%F0%9F%8C%8A%20See%20it%20in%20action.**%20In%20the%20next%20cell%2C%20change%20the%20value%20of%20the%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20variable%20%20%60changed%60%20to%20%60True%60%2C%20then%20click%20the%20run%20button.%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%22%22%22%0A%20%20%20%20)%0A)


    
    
    
    changed%20%3D%20False


            
            The order of cells on the page has no bearing on
the order in which cells are executed: marimo knows that a cell
reading a variable must run after the cell that  defines it. This
frees you to organize your code in the way that makes the most
sense for you.
            
            mo.accordion(%0A%20%20%20%20%7B%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%22Tip%3A%20execution%20order%22%3A%20(%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%22%22%22%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20The%20order%20of%20cells%20on%20the%20page%20has%20no%20bearing%20on%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20the%20order%20in%20which%20cells%20are%20executed%3A%20marimo%20knows%20that%20a%20cell%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20reading%20a%20variable%20must%20run%20after%20the%20cell%20that%20%20defines%20it.%20This%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20frees%20you%20to%20organize%20your%20code%20in%20the%20way%20that%20makes%20the%20most%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20sense%20for%20you.%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%22%22%22%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20)%0A%20%20%20%20%7D%0A)
        
Global names must be unique. To enable reactivity, marimo imposes a constraint on how names appear in cells: no two cells may define the same variable.

            
            By encapsulating logic in functions, classes, or Python modules,
you can minimize the number of global variables in your notebook.
            
            mo.accordion(%0A%20%20%20%20%7B%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%22Tip%3A%20encapsulation%22%3A%20(%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%22%22%22%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20By%20encapsulating%20logic%20in%20functions%2C%20classes%2C%20or%20Python%20modules%2C%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20you%20can%20minimize%20the%20number%20of%20global%20variables%20in%20your%20notebook.%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%22%22%22%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20)%0A%20%20%20%20%7D%0A)
        

            
            Variables prefixed with an underscore are "private" to a cell, so
they can be defined by multiple cells.
            
            mo.accordion(%0A%20%20%20%20%7B%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%22Tip%3A%20private%20variables%22%3A%20(%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%22%22%22%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20Variables%20prefixed%20with%20an%20underscore%20are%20%22private%22%20to%20a%20cell%2C%20so%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20they%20can%20be%20defined%20by%20multiple%20cells.%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%22%22%22%0A%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20)%0A%20%20%20%20%7D%0A)

title: Intro
text:
2. UI elements
Cells can output interactive UI elements. Interacting with a UI element automatically triggers notebook execution: when you interact with a UI element, its value is sent back to Python, and every cell that references that element is re-run.
marimo provides a library of UI elements to choose from under marimo.ui.  üåä Some UI elements. Try interacting with the below elements.

    
    
    
    icon%20%3D%20mo.ui.dropdown(%5B%22%F0%9F%8D%83%22%2C%20%22%F0%9F%8C%8A%22%2C%20%22%E2%9C%A8%22%5D%2C%20value%3D%22%F0%9F%8D%83%22)


    
    
    
    repetitions%20%3D%20mo.ui.slider(1%2C%2016%2C%20label%3Df%22number%20of%20%7Bicon.value%7D%3A%20%22)


    
    
    
    icon%2C%20repetitions


    
    
    
    mo.md(%22%23%20%22%20%2B%20icon.value%20*%20repetitions.value)

title: Intro
text:
3. marimo is just Python
marimo cells parse Python (and only Python), and marimo notebooks are stored as pure Python files ‚Äî outputs are not included. There‚Äôs no magical syntax.
The Python files generated by marimo are:

easily versioned with git, yielding minimal diffs
legible for both humans and machines
formattable using your tool of choice,
usable as Python scripts, with UI elements taking their default values, and
importable by other modules (more on that in the future).  ## 4. Running notebooks as apps

marimo notebooks can double as apps. Click the app window icon in the bottom-right to see this notebook in ‚Äúapp view.‚Äù
Serve a notebook as an app with marimo run at the command-line. Of course, you can use marimo just to level-up your notebooking, without ever making apps.  ## 5. The marimo command-line tool
Creating and editing notebooks. Use
marimo edit
in a terminal to start the marimo notebook server. From here you can create a new notebook or edit existing ones.
Running as apps. Use
marimo run notebook.py
to start a webserver that serves your notebook as an app in read-only mode, with code cells hidden.
Convert a Jupyter notebook. Convert a Jupyter notebook to a marimo notebook using marimo convert:
marimo convert your_notebook.ipynb > your_app.py
Tutorials. marimo comes packaged with tutorials:

dataflow: more on marimo‚Äôs automatic execution
ui: how to use UI elements
markdown: how to write markdown, with interpolated values and LaTeX
plots: how plotting works in marimo
sql: how to use SQL
layout: layout elements in marimo
fileformat: how marimo‚Äôs file format works
markdown-format: for using .md files in marimo
for-jupyter-users: if you are coming from Jupyter

Start a tutorial with marimo tutorial; for example,
marimo tutorial dataflow
In addition to tutorials, we have examples in our our GitHub repo.  ## 6. The marimo editor
Here are some tips to help you get started with the marimo editor.

            
            Saving

Name your app using the box at the top of the screen, or
  with Ctrl/Cmd+s. You can also create a named app at the
  command line, e.g., marimo edit app_name.py.
Save by clicking the save icon on the bottom right, or by
  inputting Ctrl/Cmd+s. By default marimo is configured
  to autosave.

Run a cell by clicking the play ( ‚ñ∑ ) button on the top
right of a cell, or by inputting Ctrl/Cmd+Enter.
Run a stale cell  by clicking the yellow run button on the
right of the cell, or by inputting Ctrl/Cmd+Enter. A cell is
stale when its code has been modified but not run.
Run all stale cells by clicking the play ( ‚ñ∑ ) button on
the bottom right of the screen, or input Ctrl/Cmd+Shift+r.
Console output (e.g., print() statements) is shown below a
cell.
Create a new cell above or below a given one by clicking
    the plus button to the left of the cell, which appears on
    mouse hover.
Move a cell up or down by dragging on the handle to the 
    right of the cell, which appears on mouse hover.
Delete a cell by clicking the trash bin icon. Bring it
    back by clicking the undo button on the bottom right of the
    screen, or with Ctrl/Cmd+Shift+z.
Via the notebook settings (gear icon) or footer panel, you
can disable automatic execution. This is helpful when
working with expensive notebooks or notebooks that have
side-effects like database transactions.You can disable a cell via the cell context menu.
marimo will never run a disabled cell or any cells that depend on it.
This can help prevent accidental execution of expensive computations
when editing a notebook.You can collapse or fold the code in a cell by clicking the arrow
icons in the line number column to the left, or by using keyboard
shortcuts.
Use the command palette (Ctrl/Cmd+k) or a keyboard shortcut to
quickly fold or unfold all cells.If you have ruff installed,
you can format a cell with the keyboard shortcut Ctrl/Cmd+b.Use Ctrl/Cmd+k to open the command palette.Open the notebook menu (top-right) or input Ctrl/Cmd+Shift+h to
view a list of all keyboard shortcuts.Configure the editor by clicking the gears icon near the top-right
of the screen.You can leave Marimo & shut down the server by clicking the
circled X at the top right of the screen and responding
to the prompt. 
üíæ Be sure to save your work first! 
            
            mo.accordion(tips)

title: API Reference
text:
API Reference
Project scripts (via uv run) you can advertise to contributors and maintainers.








Command
Purpose
When to use




uv run trunk-build
Build every graft listed in grafts.yaml and refresh navigation.
Regular builds in CI or before publishing.


uv run trunk-lock
Regenerate grafts.lock after successful builds.
After trunk-build to persist the manifest.


uv run graft-new --template <template> <name>
Create a new graft branch from the template.
Onboard a new section/chapter owner.


uv run graft-get <name>
Ensure a worktree exists locally for a graft branch.
When resuming work on an existing graft.


uv run graft-build --branch <name>
Build a single graft branch.
Local iteration on one section.


uv run graft-list
Show graft branches that can safely be destroyed.
Before removing stale grafts.


uv run graft-destroy <branch>
Remove a graft branch locally/remotely and clean config.
When retiring a graft.


uv run graft-cleanup-orphans
Remove .grafts/* directories no longer registered as worktrees.
Repo hygiene if worktrees drift.




Add your own helper scripts here, or link to CI workflows that run these commands.

title: Setup (trunk)
text:
Navigate to: https://github.com/jr200/quarto-graft
Click on Use this template and Create a new repository.
git clone your instantiated repo, and you will see:
(optional) If you didn‚Äôt clone all branches:

replace the contents of grafts.yaml with branches: []
create and push a new orphaned empty git branch called gh-pages.

main/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .grafts/              # local worktrees
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ docs/                 # main website
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.qmd
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ...
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ grafts__/         # (auto-generated graft content)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ grafts.yaml
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ src/quarto_graft/     # tooling



uv sync
uv run trunk-build
uv run quarto render docs --no-execute
uv run quarto preview docs
You‚Äôll see the assembled site. If you did not clone all repositories the ‚ÄòGrafts from branches‚Äô section will be empty (but that‚Äôs fine).



Apply these changes to your github repo settings.

Ensure a gh-pages branch exists.
Ensure the following are set.

Settings -> Actions -> General

Actions permissions -> Allow all actions and reusable workflows
Workflow Permissions Read and write permissions

Settings -> Pages -> Build and deployment

Source -> Deploy from a branch
Branch -> gh-pages


Point Pages at docs/_site.
Render locally or in CI, then push _site to gh-pages.




This site has github actions configured to work out-of-the-box.

Make a test commit and push from the main branch.
Check the ‚ÄòActions‚Äô page for build logs.
After some time, your site will be published.





Worktrees keep uncommitted work isolated from main.
Navigation updates happen automatically after each build.
Cleaning graft worktrees is safe-guarded; make clean-grafts will refuse to delete dirty worktrees.

text:

uv run quarto preview docs
You‚Äôll see the assembled site. If you did not clone all repositories the ‚ÄòGrafts from branches‚Äô section will be empty (but that‚Äôs fine).

title: Setup (trunk)
text:
Worktrees keep uncommitted work isolated from main.
Navigation updates happen automatically after each build.
Cleaning graft worktrees is safe-guarded; make clean-grafts will refuse to delete dirty worktrees.

title: Setup (graft)
text:
This step can be done by the contributor, or the trunk maintainer.
Clone the repo and create a new graft.
git clone ...
uv run graft-new  --template py-jupyter my-first-graft
This will create a and push a git branch graft/my-first-graft, also updating the grafts.yaml configuration file. The grafts.lock manifest can be updated by running:
uv run trunk-build
You can preview the new graft in the hierarchy using.
uv run quarto preview docs
Each graft template carries its own:
my-first-graft/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ docs/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.qmd
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ _quarto.yaml
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .gitignore
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Makefile
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md



The branch is an entirely isolated quartodoc project and knows nothing about the trunk.
The only contract is the following command must succeed using the python dependencies of the trunk.
uv run quarto render docs
Save and push changes to the remote.
git commit -am "added new graft called 'my-first-graft'"
git push
Note: the main trunk does not execute any scripts. This means outputs in notebooks need to be committed to the branch if they should be shown on the main website.



To see what can be safely removed, run:
uv run graft-list
Then destroy a specific graft branch (local, remote, and config entries) with:
uv run graft-destroy graft/my-first-graft

title: Contributing
text:
A template is a ready-to-use graft skeleton (project structure, language/tooling, Quarto settings, navigation, dependency strategy). New graft branches start from whatever template lives on the protected template branch.



Runs immediately with make preview.
Includes the basics:

docs/
_quarto.yaml
Makefile
pyproject.toml (or equivalent for the stack)

Clearly shows:

the primary language/toolchain,
how outputs are rendered,
how notebooks or scripts are handled.






Python + Jupyter + Polars
R + Quarto + ggplot
JavaScript + Observable + WASM
Book-style chapters vs website-style sections
Research reproducibility templates
Internal documentation templates





Open a PR to main with your proposed template changes.
Maintainers review for structure, safety, and ergonomics.
Once accepted, maintainers promote it into the protected template branch.
Contributors automatically inherit the updated template when they create new grafts.


Important: No one opens PRs directly into the protected template branch; it remains maintainer-controlled.

title: quarto-graft
text:
Compose a single Quarto site from branch-scoped worktrees.

Quarto Graft lets contributors build chapters, sections, or full sub-sites in isolated git branches while the trunk assembles everything into one fully searchable Quarto website.


Traditional versioned collaboration forces everyone into main, leading to merge conflicts, shared heavy dependencies, and a single project shape. Quarto Graft flips that model:

Each contributor owns one branch = one self-contained chapter/section with its own language, environment, and runtime.
The trunk never executes contributor code; it only ingests rendered artifacts, keeping main fast and stable.
Broken branches don‚Äôt block the site: last-good fallbacks keep content online with visible warnings.





Ready-to-publish Quarto scaffold (navbar, sidebar, favicon, footer, search, GitHub links).
Branch-grafting build system using git worktrees + uv and automatic navigation updates.
Clean contributor workflow: no cross-branch conflicts or shared dependency coupling; full local preview per branch.
Failure handling: last-good fallbacks and visible broken-branch stubs.





Multi-author books and research publications
Quant/science teams and education platforms
Internal documentation portals
‚Ä¶anybody who wants to track and version threads in isolation




quarto-graft is released under the MIT License. You are free to use, modify, and redistribute it with attribution.

title: quarto-graft
text: quarto-graft is released under the MIT License. You are free to use, modify, and redistribute it with attribution.

title: Glossary
text:
Glossary

Graft: A git branch containing Quarto content that will be mounted into the trunk site.
Trunk: The main branch that controls grafts.yaml, runs builds, and publishes.
Worktree: A checked-out view of a branch living under .grafts/<name>, keeping contributor work isolated.
Export: The rendered output from a graft branch under docs/grafts__/.

title: marimo-demo: Marimo + Quarto
text:
Welcome! This graft shows how to pair Quarto with a small Python package and a self-contained marimo widget exported to HTML.



uv-managed project with a package at src/marimo_demo/
marimo + polars dependencies pre-wired for client-side interactivity
A marimo app at docs/marimo_app.py that exports to docs/marimo-demo.html
Quarto site with navbar/sidebar linking to the exported HTML
Make targets to export the app and render the site




uv sync
make render          # exports marimo_app.py -> marimo-demo.html and renders Quarto
Then open _site/index.html or run make preview. Use the sidebar or navbar to open marimo-demo.html and play with the widget (fully client-side, no runtime server).




The marimo app lives in docs/marimo_app.py.
make render runs marimo export to build docs/marimo-demo.html with embedded assets.
Quarto copies that HTML into _site/ and links it in the nav.




The core of marimo_app.py:
@mo.app
def app():
    sales = demo_sales_data()
    region = mo.ui.dropdown(options=["All"] + sorted(sales.get_column("region").unique().to_list()), value="All")
    min_revenue = mo.ui.slider(start=0, stop=int(sales.get_column("revenue").max()), step=25, value=200)
    top_n = mo.ui.slider(start=3, stop=10, value=5, step=1)

    filtered = sales
    if region.value != "All":
        filtered = filtered.filter(pl.col("region") == region.value)
    filtered = (
        filtered.filter(pl.col("revenue") >= min_revenue.value)
        .sort("revenue", descending=True)
        .head(top_n.value)
    )

    return mo.vstack(
        [
            mo.md(f"{greet()} Explore the sample sales data."),
            mo.hstack([region, min_revenue, top_n], wrap=True, gap="0.75rem"),
            mo.ui.table(filtered.to_dict(as_series=False)),
        ],
        gap="0.75rem",
    )




Swap demo_sales_data for your own loader and schema.
Add more UI pieces (mo.ui.select, mo.ui.switch, mo.ui.number) and marimo will keep outputs in sync.
To ship elsewhere, just copy _site/marimo-demo.html (it‚Äôs self contained).

title: marimo-demo: Marimo + Quarto
text:
uv-managed project with a package at src/marimo_demo/
marimo + polars dependencies pre-wired for client-side interactivity
A marimo app at docs/marimo_app.py that exports to docs/marimo-demo.html
Quarto site with navbar/sidebar linking to the exported HTML
Make targets to export the app and render the site

title: marimo-demo: Marimo + Quarto
text:
uv sync
make render          # exports marimo_app.py -> marimo-demo.html and renders Quarto
Then open _site/index.html or run make preview. Use the sidebar or navbar to open marimo-demo.html and play with the widget (fully client-side, no runtime server).

title: marimo-demo: Marimo + Quarto
text:
The marimo app lives in docs/marimo_app.py.
make render runs marimo export to build docs/marimo-demo.html with embedded assets.
Quarto copies that HTML into _site/ and links it in the nav.

title: marimo-demo: Marimo + Quarto
marimo-demo: Marimo + Quarto
text:
Swap demo_sales_data for your own loader and schema.
Add more UI pieces (mo.ui.select, mo.ui.switch, mo.ui.number) and marimo will keep outputs in sync.
To ship elsewhere, just copy _site/marimo-demo.html (it‚Äôs self contained).

title: Overview
text:
Welcome to the markdown-demo graft. This is a lightweight Markdown starter for teams that just need prose and simple code fences.



Replace this page with your own content.
Add more .qmd or .md files under docs/ and link them via the sidebar.
Run make render (or quarto render docs) to build _site/.

Happy writing!

title: Overview
text:
Welcome to the jupyter-demo graft. This starter shows how to ship a small Python package and surface it in Quarto content (including notebooks).



uv-managed project with a package at src/jupyter_demo/
Quarto site with navbar/sidebar and a pre-rendered demo notebook
Simple helpers exported from the package




uv sync
uv run quarto render docs --no-execute
Then open _site/index.html or run make preview.



```python from jupyter_demo import greet, show_dataframe greet(‚ÄúQuarto‚Äù)
show_dataframe() ```d
See notebook.ipynb for a jupyter notebook example.
